AvProblem.comment: in rain-impacted areas slides/wet avalanches, also glide-snow avalanches

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Trigger-prone snowdrifts, wet avalanches due to rain, increasing glide-snow avalanches
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Fresh snow and drifts are trigger-prone and the main danger at high altitudes. Danger zones occur in ridgeline terrain, behind discontinuities and in wind-loaded gullies and bowls. Small-to-medium sized avalanches can be triggered by one person. Pay attention to the risks of falling and being swept along. Where there is rain impact, wet slides and avalanches are possible. On steep grass-covered slopes and rocky plates in all aspects, increasing small-to-medium glide-snow avalanches are possible, avoid zones below glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Regionally wind strength is intensifying, fresh and old snow is being transported. Fresh drifts are often deposited atop soft loose old snowpack layers or, esp in shady steep terrain, atop surface hoar and are prone to triggering. Zones which are rain-impacted have a weakened snowpack. The old snowpack is well consolidated and stable. The warm ground and wet lower layers are reinforcing the gliding movement of the entire snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.wxSynopsisComment: Nocturnal hours: Widespread rainfall and snowfall from the southwest, snowfall level dropping first to 2000 m, then to 1600 m. At high altitudes: 5 cm fresh snow expected. Thursday daytime: Dry for a short while. Reduced visibility due to fog, 10-30 cm snowfall expected. At 2000 m: +1 degree at midday, -6 degrees by evening. Brisk to strong westerly winds.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: On Friday, snow showers will taper off, it will turn increasingly sunny. Danger of wet-snow avalanches will recede. Snowdrifts and gliding snow will remain the big problems.

AvProblem.comment: >2000 m: behind discontinuities, wind-loaded gullies, bowls
in rain-impacted areas slides/wet avalanches, also glide-snow avalanches

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh snowdrifts at high altitudes, wet avalanches due to rain
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Fresh snow and drifts are trigger-prone and the main danger at high altitudes. Danger zones occur in ridgeline terrain, behind discontinuities and in wind-loaded gullies and bowls. Small-to-medium sized avalanches can be triggered by one person. Pay attention to the risks of falling and being swept along. Where there is rain impact, wet slides and avalanches are possible. On steep grass-covered slopes and rocky plates in all aspects, increasing small-to-medium glide-snow avalanches are possible, avoid zones below glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Regionally wind strength is intensifying, fresh and old snow is being transported. Fresh drifts are often deposited atop soft loose old snowpack layers or, esp in shady steep terrain, atop surface hoar and are prone to triggering. Zones which are rain-impacted have a weakened snowpack. The old snowpack is well consolidated and stable. The warm ground and wet lower layers are reinforcing the gliding movement of the entire snowpack.

Brisk to strong westerly winds.
